Package com.foreach.across.modules.entity.bind

Class EntityPropertyControlName

java.lang.Object
com.foreach.across.modules.entity.bind.EntityPropertyControlName
Direct Known Subclasses:
EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty, EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty.BinderProperty, EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty.BinderProperty.BinderPropertyValue
public abstract class EntityPropertyControlName extends Object
Helper for generating a control name that can be used to bind to a property, both directly or by using an EntityPropertiesBinder. Supports multiple types of control name generation.

The actual control name to use can be retrieved by simply calling Object.toString().

Simple control name examples:

  • forProperty("user") -> user
  • forProperty("user").asBinderItem() -> properties[user].value
  • forProperty("user").forChildProperty("address") -> user.address
  • forProperty("user").forChildProperty("address").asBinderItem() -> properties[user].properties[address].value
  • forProperty("user").asBinderItem().forChildProperty("address") -> properties[user].value.address
  • forProperty("user").asBinderItem().withInitializedValue() -> properties[user].initializedValue
To work with collection items and map entry control names, see the EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty.asCollectionItem() and EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty.asMapEntry() javadoc.

It is also possible to specify a root control name that should prefix generated properties, see root(String) for more details.

Since:
3.2.0
Author:
Arne Vandamme

  • Field Details

    • DEFAULT_BINDER_PREFIX

      public static final String DEFAULT_BINDER_PREFIX
      Default EntityPropertiesBinder prefix: this is the property path where the binder can be found if it is the direct target of a DataBinder. The default value links to EntityPropertiesBinder.getProperties().
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

  • Method Details

    • forProperty

      public static EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forProperty(@NonNull @NonNull String propertyName)
      Create a control name for the property with the given name.
      Parameters:
      propertyName - name of the property
      Returns:
      control name for property

    • forProperty

      public static EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forProperty(@NonNull @NonNull String propertyName, @NonNull @NonNull String binderPrefix)
      Create a control name for the property with the given name, and a custom binder prefix. The binder prefix is the base binding path where the EntityPropertiesBinder is available. If you bind directly on the EntityPropertiesBinder, the default is binder prefix (properties) which will call EntityPropertiesBinder.getProperties().

      In some cases (with an EntityViewCommand for example), the actual EntityPropertiesBinder is registered under a different property. For example, assume you have a custom binder target: 

      
 class BinderTarget {
     EntityPropertiesBinder getPropertyData();
 }
      In this case propertyData would be the correct binder prefix to use.
      Parameters:
      propertyName - name of the property
      binderPrefix - binder prefix to use
      Returns:
      control name for the property

    • forProperty

      public static EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forProperty(@NonNull @NonNull EntityPropertyDescriptor descriptor)
      Create a control name for the property descriptor.

      In case of a nested descriptor, a control name hierarchy will be built, taking into account the EntityPropertyHandlingType of the parent descriptors. If a parent descriptor has specified that it should bind values using the EntityPropertiesBinder instead of directly, the control name returned will use the binder path for the parent item.

      Likewise, if the descriptor explicitly specifies a EntityPropertyHandlingType.MANUAL handling type, the parents will be ignored and the descriptor name is expected to be absolute. If an EntityAttributes.CONTROL_NAME is registered, that value will be used as property name instead.

      Parameters:
      descriptor - for which to generate the control name
      Returns:
      control name for the property

    • forProperty

      public static EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forProperty(@NonNull @NonNull EntityPropertyDescriptor descriptor, @NonNull @NonNull String binderPrefix)
      Create a control name for the property descriptor.

      In case of a nested descriptor, a control name hierarchy will be built, taking into account the EntityPropertyHandlingType of the parent descriptors. If a parent descriptor has specified that it should bind values using the EntityPropertiesBinder instead of directly, the control name returned will use the binder path for the parent item.

      Likewise, if the descriptor explicitly specifies a EntityPropertyHandlingType.MANUAL handling type, the parents will be ignored and the descriptor name is expected to be absolute. If an EntityAttributes.CONTROL_NAME is registered, that value will be used as property name instead.

      Parameters:
      descriptor - for which to generate the control name
      binderPrefix - binder prefix to use
      Returns:
      control name for the property

    • forProperty

      public static EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forProperty(@NonNull @NonNull EntityPropertyDescriptor descriptor, @NonNull @NonNull com.foreach.across.modules.web.ui.ViewElementBuilderContext builderContext)
      Create a control name for the property descriptor, using a parent EntityPropertyControlName if one is registered on the ViewElementBuilderContext. If the builder context contains a EntityPropertyControlName attribute, the actual control name will be generated using forChildProperty(EntityPropertyDescriptor), else it will be the equivalent as a call to forProperty(EntityPropertyDescriptor).

      This approach can be used for nested control name building, where you need to ensure that a control name is a child of a specific collection item path for example. In the same way it can be use to register a root(String) control name, and ensure that all direct property paths are generated with a base prefix, or a custom prefix for the main EntityPropertiesBinder is being used.

      Parameters:
      descriptor - for which to generate the control name
      builderContext - to inspect for a parent EntityPropertyControlName
      Returns:
      control name for the property

    • root

      public static EntityPropertyControlName root(@NonNull @NonNull String prefix)
      Create a root control name which only behaves a direct path prefix, but does not impact transitive binding. For example, executing: root("entity").forChildProperty("user") would return entity.user as the direct property path, but would still return properties[user] as binder item.

      Comparatively: forProperty("entity").forChildProperty("user") would also return entity.user as direct property path, but would return properties[entity].properties[user] as binder item.

      A root control name can be registered on the ViewElementBuilderContext to ensure that all control names follow a base path, by generating them using forProperty(EntityPropertyDescriptor, ViewElementBuilderContext).

      Parameters:
      prefix - direct property path prefix that should always be added
      Returns:
      root control name
      See Also:
      • root(String, String)

    • root

      public static EntityPropertyControlName root(@NonNull @NonNull String prefix, @NonNull @NonNull String binderPrefix)
      Create a root control name which only behaves a direct path prefix, but does not impact transitive binding. For example, executing: root("entity").forChildProperty("user") would return entity.user as the direct property path, but would still return properties[user] as binder item.

      Comparatively: forProperty("entity").forChildProperty("user") would also return entity.user as direct property path, but would return properties[entity].properties[user] as binder item.

      A root control name can be registered on the ViewElementBuilderContext to ensure that all control names follow a base path, by generating them using forProperty(EntityPropertyDescriptor, ViewElementBuilderContext).

      Parameters:
      prefix - direct property path prefix that should always be added
      Returns:
      root control name
      See Also:
      • root(String, String)

    • forChildProperty

      public EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forChildProperty(@NonNull @NonNull String propertyName)
      Create a control name for a child property of the current control name. How exactly the control name gets generated depends on the current EntityPropertyControlName implementation.

      In its most simple form, suppose the current control name has a direct path user. Calling forChildProperty("address") will return a control name with the direct path user.address.

      Parameters:
      propertyName - name of the property
      Returns:
      property control name

    • forChildProperty

      public EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty forChildProperty(@NonNull @NonNull EntityPropertyDescriptor descriptor)
      Create a control name for a child property of the current control name, with the EntityPropertyDescriptor representing the child property. Both the current control name implementation and the descriptor settings will determine how exactly the control name gets generated.

      If the descriptor explicitly specifies a EntityPropertyHandlingType.MANUAL handling type, the parents will be ignored and the descriptor name is expected to be absolute. If an EntityAttributes.CONTROL_NAME is registered, that value will be used as property name instead.

      If the descriptor is a nested descriptor, the parent control name will be matched against the property name and stripped off as a prefix. Suppose the parent control name is user and the descriptor has name user.address. A non-nested descriptor would generate control name user.user.address whereas a nested descriptor will return user.address.

      Parameters:
      descriptor - for the property
      Returns:
      property control name

    • asProperty

      public abstract EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty asProperty()
      Return the base property control name that was used to create the current one. If the current control name is a specific type (for example a EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty.BinderProperty) then this will return the EntityPropertyControlName.ForProperty instance that was used to create it.
      Returns:
      the property control name that was the basis for the current one
